newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan seeks bids for second mobile phone network.
newsitem.headline: Jordan seeks bids for second mobile phone network.

text.p: Jordan will announce a tender in March for a second mobile phone licence, breaking a monopoly which has existed since mobile phones were introduced to the kingdom in 1994, officials said on Tuesday.
Youssef Abu Jamous, director-general of Jordan's Telecommunications Regulatory Commission (TRC), said the search for a second operator aimed to cut prices for phone users.
"Competition is the name of the game," he told Reuters.
The TRC will formally announce the tender in March, but it is seeking preliminary applications by the end of January.

Those applications should give details of qualification to operate the system, compatibility with the existing operator, and proposed radio spectrums, licence fees, rates and geographical area covered by the phones.

Jordan, facing a serious shortage of fixed telephone lines, signed an exclusive four-year deal in 1994 with Jordan Mobile Telephone Services Company (JMTSC). The company is owned by Jordanian businessmen but the system was built up by U.S. firm Motorola Inc.
The new operator will be allowed to start in parallel with JMTSC in November 1998, when the exclusive deal runs out.
Abu Jamous said Jordan might accept more than one offer if the terms were attractive.

He said the TRC would set a price cap on customer charges once other operators started. Charges currently stand at 70 dinars ($100) for installation, 21 dinars per month subscription, and 180 fils to 245 fils a minute for local calls a peak rates.
"The trend is for cellular phones and once the price is reasonable, people will prefer them," Abu Jamous said. Jordan now has around 27,000 mobile phone subscribers, he said.
